content: quote: An Israeli military college has printed damning soldiers' accounts of the killing of civilians and vandalism during recent operations in Gaza. One account tells of a sniper killing a mother and children at close range whom troops had told to leave their home. Another speaker at the seminar described what he saw as the "cold blooded murder" of a Palestinian woman. The army has defended its conduct during the Gaza offensive but said it would investigate the testimonies. The Israeli army has said it will investigate the soldiers' accounts. The testimonies were published by the military academy at Oranim College. Graduates of the academy, who had served in Gaza, were speaking to new recruits at a seminar. "[The testimonies] conveyed an atmosphere in which one feels entitled to use unrestricted force against Palestinians," academy director Dany Zamir told public radio. (....) The Palestinian woman and two of her children were allegedly shot after they misunderstood instructions about which way to walk having been ordered out of their home by troops. "The climate in general... I don't know how to describe it.... the lives of Palestinians, let's say, are much, much less important than the lives of our soldiers," an infantry squad leader is quoted saying. In another cited case, a commander ordered troops to kill an elderly woman walking on a road, even though she was easily identifiable and clearly not a threat. Testimonies, which were given by combat pilots and infantry soldiers, also included allegations of unnecessary destruction of Palestinian property. "We would throw everything out of the windows to make room and order. Everything... Refrigerators, plates, furniture. The order was to throw all of the house's contents outside," a soldier said. One non-commissioned officer related at the seminar that an old woman crossing a main road was shot by soldiers. "I don't know whether she was suspicious, not suspicious, I don't know her story… I do know that my officer sent people to the roof in order to take her out… It was cold-blooded murder," he said. (....) The soldiers' testimonies also reportedly told of an unusually high intervention by military and non-military rabbis, who circulated pamphlets describing the war in religious terminology. "All the articles had one clear message," one soldier said. "We are the people of Israel, we arrived in the country almost by miracle, now we need to fight to uproot the gentiles who interfere with re-conquering the Holy Land." "Many soldiers' feelings were that this was a war of religion," he added. (....) Medical authorities say more than 1,300 Palestinians were killed during Israel's 22-day operation, including some 440 children, 110 women, and dozens of elderly people. (....) I want to hear the usual armchair generals tell us these troops are laying! +http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/7952603.stm

content: They're not lying, but soldiers aren't social workers. Their prime functions, despite all the positive media, are to kill things and wreck stuff in an organized fashion. Those are the basics of military training: organization and the use of arms. Add to that 'indoctrination', which can vary with circumstance, and you have the stuff of which some PTSD is made. Such 'discussion' wouldn't be far 'out of place' in any barrack. Even one of the SS. But based on such testimony, and action on a larger scale, the world decided that was a 'criminal organization'. 'Cast Lead' was the contrived military punishment of a civilian population pure and simple. An exercise in applied indoctrination.
reply: They're not lying, but soldiers aren't social workers. Their prime functions, despite all the positive media, are to kill things and wreck stuff in an organized fashion. Those are the basics of military training: organization and the use of arms. Add to that 'indoctrination', which can vary with circumstance, and you have the stuff of which some PTSD is made. Such 'discussion' wouldn't be far 'out of place' in any barrack. Even one of the SS. But based on such testimony, and action on a larger scale, the world decided that was a 'criminal organization'. 'Cast Lead' was the contrived military punishment of a civilian population pure and simple. An exercise in applied indoctrination.
title: Israel troops admit Gaza abuses

content: Pops, is that REALLY you? Knele- 1)The operation was not one of religion. Some rabbis probably thought so, but you have such idiots everywhere. 2)The particular story about the sniper, is told with a bias, which sheds light on your source. The mother was told to turn right when she exited the building, she turned by mistake, to the left instead. The soldier had identified an unauthorized person in a "dead zone" and shot her. "http://news.walla.co.il/?w=/1/1454581" I will repeat myself again-in Gaza there will be ALWAYS high number of "children, women and various innocents". Pillow kids, hamas killing them, we killing them by mistake, (or not, if some idiot is really trigger happy). However, trigger happy idiots are a rarity in IDF. 3)Being arm-chair ggeneral yourself, knele, you have no right to accuse me (since i guess you have had me in mind) of being arm-chair general. Unlike you, i was there.

I don't know how to describe it.... the lives of Palestinians, let's say, are much, much less important than the lives of our soldiers," an infantry squad leader is quoted saying. content: I for one have no reason to believe that this account is not reasonably accurate. War is an unfortunate situation that creates worse conditions for all the participants, and like it or not everyone is a participant. That said and in the interest of fair and balanced reporting where is the companion piece citing the misdeeds of the Pals? It is not possible nor plausible that they maintained squeaky clean before, during or after this conflict.
reply: I for one have no reason to believe that this account is not reasonably accurate. That said and in the interest of fair and balanced reporting where is the companion piece citing the misdeeds of the Pals? It is not possible nor plausible that they maintained squeaky clean before, during or after this conflict.

content: Apparently, some IDF Soldiers dont agree that crimes were committed on a Mass scale XXXhttp://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3689388,00.htmlXXX (Israeli News Source) IDF soldiers refute claims of immoral conduct in Gaza 'It is true that in war morality can be interpreted in many different ways, and there are always a few idiots who act inappropriately, but most of the troops represented Israel honorably,' soldier says in response to claims of immoral behavior during Operation Cast Lead. Reservist: Claims 'fictitious' Major (res.) Idan Zuaretz of Givati said "in every war there is a small percentage of problematic soldiers, but we must look at it from a broad perspective and not focus on isolated incidents. Zuaretz, a company commander, also questioned the integrity of the soldiers who made the controversial claims, saying "if this was such a burning issue for them, why have they remained silent until now? On an ethical and moral level, they were obligated to stop what they claimed had occurred and not wait two months to be heard at some esoteric debate." According to the officer, the IDF went to great lengths and employed the most advanced technology to avoid harming civilian population. "I've seen a few things in my time, but even I was blown away by the level of professionalism displayed by the army," Zuaretz said. "I personally gave my soldiers an order on the day we withdrew from Gaza to leave all of our goodies in the last house we occupied. Some reservists even left an envelope full of money to one Palestinian family."

Reservist: Claims 'fictitious' Major (res.) Idan Zuaretz of Givati said "in every war there is a small percentage of problematic soldiers, but we must look at it from a broad perspective and not focus on isolated incidents. Zuaretz, a company commander, also questioned the integrity of the soldiers who made the controversial claims, saying "if this was such a burning issue for them, why have they remained silent until now? On an ethical and moral level, they were obligated to stop what they claimed had occurred and not wait two months to be heard at some esoteric debate." According to the officer, the IDF went to great lengths and employed the most advanced technology to avoid harming civilian population. "I've seen a few things in my time, but even I was blown away by the level of professionalism displayed by the army," Zuaretz said. "I personally gave my soldiers an order on the day we withdrew from Gaza to leave all of our goodies in the last house we occupied. Some reservists even left an envelope full of money to one Palestinian family."

War is an unfortunate situation that creates worse conditions for all the participants, and like it or not everyone is a participant. That said and in the interest of fair and balanced reporting where is the companion piece citing the misdeeds of the Pals? It is not possible nor plausible that they maintained squeaky clean before, during or after this conflict. It must not be part of certain agendas. Otherwise we might have been notified. Todays politics remind me of an old saying. - "Ideas are more powerful than guns. We would not let our enemies have guns, why should we let them have ideas?" - Joseph Stalin

Reservist: Claims 'fictitious' Major (res.) Idan Zuaretz of Givati said "in every war there is a small percentage of problematic soldiers, but we must look at it from a broad perspective and not focus on isolated incidents. Zuaretz, a company commander, also questioned the integrity of the soldiers who made the controversial claims, saying "if this was such a burning issue for them, why have they remained silent until now? On an ethical and moral level, they were obligated to stop what they claimed had occurred and not wait two months to be heard at some esoteric debate." According to the officer, the IDF went to great lengths and employed the most advanced technology to avoid harming civilian population. "I've seen a few things in my time, but even I was blown away by the level of professionalism displayed by the army," Zuaretz said. Some reservists even left an envelope full of money to one Palestinian family." How much is 'mass' - seen Gaza? Somebody's full of it. They should give the 'problem' soldiers and idiots a shovel - not a tank, or a sniper's rifle. If they had to get somebody's brains on themselves at least you'd know who they were. As it is, one, or a few 'bad apples' can spoil the good name, honor, etc of all the rest who serve. They have been notoriously effective at getting innocent servants spat upon. The pity is that warriors like yourself can't fully appreciate what you're about until some like-minded individual on the other side, does the same thing to you, and yours. Until then, incidents like this are about soldiers in 'bad' situations and the mere civilians who get the punishment, and the blame. This message has been edited. content: quote: Israelis on Friday got a fuller dose of rank-and-file angst over their army's winter assault on the Gaza Strip, as newspapers elaborated on allegations that commanders created a permissive attitude toward the killing of civilians. Soldiers' accounts of two killings of women and children appeared Thursday in Haaretz and Maariv. Both papers followed up Friday with lengthy excerpts of the soldiers’ comments about confusion and doubt over the rules of engagement during the 22-day offensive, which left an estimated 1,400 Palestinians dead. (....) +http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-gaza-israeli-troops21-2009mar21,0,2555966.story
quote: Israelis on Friday got a fuller dose of rank-and-file angst over their army's winter assault on the Gaza Strip, as newspapers elaborated on allegations that commanders created a permissive attitude toward the killing of civilians. Soldiers' accounts of two killings of women and children appeared Thursday in Haaretz and Maariv. Both papers followed up Friday with lengthy excerpts of the soldiers’ comments about confusion and doubt over the rules of engagement during the 22-day offensive, which left an estimated 1,400 Palestinians dead. (....)
reply: +http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-gaza-israeli-troops21-2009mar21,0,2555966.story
title: Israel troops admit Gaza abuses

title: Israel troops admit Gaza abuses

content: quote: An Israeli military college has printed damning soldiers' accounts of the killing of civilians and vandalism during recent operations in Gaza. One account tells of a sniper killing a mother and children at close range whom troops had told to leave their home. Another speaker at the seminar described what he saw as the "cold blooded murder" of a Palestinian woman. The army has defended its conduct during the Gaza offensive but said it would investigate the testimonies. The Israeli army has said it will investigate the soldiers' accounts. The testimonies were published by the military academy at Oranim College. Graduates of the academy, who had served in Gaza, were speaking to new recruits at a seminar. "[The testimonies] conveyed an atmosphere in which one feels entitled to use unrestricted force against Palestinians," academy director Dany Zamir told public radio. (....) The Palestinian woman and two of her children were allegedly shot after they misunderstood instructions about which way to walk having been ordered out of their home by troops. "The climate in general... I don't know how to describe it.... the lives of Palestinians, let's say, are much, much less important than the lives of our soldiers," an infantry squad leader is quoted saying. In another cited case, a commander ordered troops to kill an elderly woman walking on a road, even though she was easily identifiable and clearly not a threat. Testimonies, which were given by combat pilots and infantry soldiers, also included allegations of unnecessary destruction of Palestinian property. "We would throw everything out of the windows to make room and order. Everything... Refrigerators, plates, furniture. The order was to throw all of the house's contents outside," a soldier said. One non-commissioned officer related at the seminar that an old woman crossing a main road was shot by soldiers. "I don't know whether she was suspicious, not suspicious, I don't know her story… I do know that my officer sent people to the roof in order to take her out… It was cold-blooded murder," he said. (....) The soldiers' testimonies also reportedly told of an unusually high intervention by military and non-military rabbis, who circulated pamphlets describing the war in religious terminology. "All the articles had one clear message," one soldier said. "We are the people of Israel, we arrived in the country almost by miracle, now we need to fight to uproot the gentiles who interfere with re-conquering the Holy Land." "Many soldiers' feelings were that this was a war of religion," he added. (....) Medical authorities say more than 1,300 Palestinians were killed during Israel's 22-day operation, including some 440 children, 110 women, and dozens of elderly people. (....) I want to hear the usual armchair generals tell us these troops are laying! +http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/7952603.stm

content: They're not lying, but soldiers aren't social workers. Their prime functions, despite all the positive media, are to kill things and wreck stuff in an organized fashion. Those are the basics of military training: organization and the use of arms. Add to that 'indoctrination', which can vary with circumstance, and you have the stuff of which some PTSD is made. Such 'discussion' wouldn't be far 'out of place' in any barrack. Even one of the SS. But based on such testimony, and action on a larger scale, the world decided that was a 'criminal organization'. 'Cast Lead' was the contrived military punishment of a civilian population pure and simple. An exercise in applied indoctrination.
reply: They're not lying, but soldiers aren't social workers. Their prime functions, despite all the positive media, are to kill things and wreck stuff in an organized fashion. Those are the basics of military training: organization and the use of arms. Add to that 'indoctrination', which can vary with circumstance, and you have the stuff of which some PTSD is made. Such 'discussion' wouldn't be far 'out of place' in any barrack. Even one of the SS. But based on such testimony, and action on a larger scale, the world decided that was a 'criminal organization'. content: Pops, is that REALLY you? Knele- 1)The operation was not one of religion. Some rabbis probably thought so, but you have such idiots everywhere. 2)The particular story about the sniper, is told with a bias, which sheds light on your source. The mother was told to turn right when she exited the building, she turned by mistake, to the left instead. The soldier had identified an unauthorized person in a "dead zone" and shot her. "http://news.walla.co.il/?w=/1/1454581" I will repeat myself again-in Gaza there will be ALWAYS high number of "children, women and various innocents". Pillow kids, hamas killing them, we killing them by mistake, (or not, if some idiot is really trigger happy). However, trigger happy idiots are a rarity in IDF. 3)Being arm-chair ggeneral yourself, knele, you have no right to accuse me (since i guess you have had me in mind) of being arm-chair general. Unlike you, i was there.

content: I for one have no reason to believe that this account is not reasonably accurate. War is an unfortunate situation that creates worse conditions for all the participants, and like it or not everyone is a participant. That said and in the interest of fair and balanced reporting where is the companion piece citing the misdeeds of the Pals? It is not possible nor plausible that they maintained squeaky clean before, during or after this conflict.
reply: I for one have no reason to believe that this account is not reasonably accurate. It is not possible nor plausible that they maintained squeaky clean before, during or after this conflict.

content: Apparently, some IDF Soldiers dont agree that crimes were committed on a Mass scale XXXhttp://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3689388,00.htmlXXX (Israeli News Source) IDF soldiers refute claims of immoral conduct in Gaza 'It is true that in war morality can be interpreted in many different ways, and there are always a few idiots who act inappropriately, but most of the troops represented Israel honorably,' soldier says in response to claims of immoral behavior during Operation Cast Lead. Reservist: Claims 'fictitious' Major (res.) Idan Zuaretz of Givati said "in every war there is a small percentage of problematic soldiers, but we must look at it from a broad perspective and not focus on isolated incidents. Zuaretz, a company commander, also questioned the integrity of the soldiers who made the controversial claims, saying "if this was such a burning issue for them, why have they remained silent until now? On an ethical and moral level, they were obligated to stop what they claimed had occurred and not wait two months to be heard at some esoteric debate." According to the officer, the IDF went to great lengths and employed the most advanced technology to avoid harming civilian population. "I've seen a few things in my time, but even I was blown away by the level of professionalism displayed by the army," Zuaretz said. "I personally gave my soldiers an order on the day we withdrew from Gaza to leave all of our goodies in the last house we occupied. Some reservists even left an envelope full of money to one Palestinian family."

Reservist: Claims 'fictitious' Major (res.) Idan Zuaretz of Givati said "in every war there is a small percentage of problematic soldiers, but we must look at it from a broad perspective and not focus on isolated incidents. Zuaretz, a company commander, also questioned the integrity of the soldiers who made the controversial claims, saying "if this was such a burning issue for them, why have they remained silent until now? On an ethical and moral level, they were obligated to stop what they claimed had occurred and not wait two months to be heard at some esoteric debate." According to the officer, the IDF went to great lengths and employed the most advanced technology to avoid harming civilian population. "I've seen a few things in my time, but even I was blown away by the level of professionalism displayed by the army," Zuaretz said. "I personally gave my soldiers an order on the day we withdrew from Gaza to leave all of our goodies in the last house we occupied. Some reservists even left an envelope full of money to one Palestinian family."

According to the officer, the IDF went to great lengths and employed the most advanced technology to avoid harming civilian population. "I've seen a few things in my time, but even I was blown away by the level of professionalism displayed by the army," Zuaretz said. "I personally gave my soldiers an order on the day we withdrew from Gaza to leave all of our goodies in the last house we occupied. Some reservists even left an envelope full of money to one Palestinian family." How much is 'mass' - seen Gaza? Somebody's full of it. They should give the 'problem' soldiers and idiots a shovel - not a tank, or a sniper's rifle. If they had to get somebody's brains on themselves at least you'd know who they were. As it is, one, or a few 'bad apples' can spoil the good name, honor, etc of all the rest who serve. They have been notoriously effective at getting innocent servants spat upon. The pity is that warriors like yourself can't fully appreciate what you're about until some like-minded individual on the other side, does the same thing to you, and yours. Until then, incidents like this are about soldiers in 'bad' situations and the mere civilians who get the punishment, and the blame. This message has been edited. Last edited by: popsiq, Fri 20 March 2009 09:23 PM
quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: Apparently, some IDF Soldiers dont agree that crimes were committed on a Mass scale XXXhttp://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3689388,00.htmlXXX (Israeli News Source) IDF soldiers refute claims of immoral conduct in Gaza 'It is true that in war morality can be interpreted in many different ways, and there are always a few idiots who act inappropriately, but most of the troops represented Israel honorably,' soldier says in response to claims of immoral behavior during Operation Cast Lead. Reservist: Claims 'fictitious' Major (res.) Idan Zuaretz of Givati said "in every war there is a small percentage of problematic soldiers, but we must look at it from a broad perspective and not focus on isolated incidents. Zuaretz, a company commander, also questioned the integrity of the soldiers who made the controversial claims, saying "if this was such a burning issue for them, why have they remained silent until now? On an ethical and moral level, they were obligated to stop what they claimed had occurred and not wait two months to be heard at some esoteric debate." According to the officer, the IDF went to great lengths and employed the most advanced technology to avoid harming civilian population. "I've seen a few things in my time, but even I was blown away by the level of professionalism displayed by the army," Zuaretz said. "I personally gave my soldiers an order on the day we withdrew from Gaza to leave all of our goodies in the last house we occupied. Some reservists even left an envelope full of money to one Palestinian family."
reply: How much is 'mass' - seen Gaza? Somebody's full of it. They should give the 'problem' soldiers and idiots a shovel - not a tank, or a sniper's rifle. If they had to get somebody's brains on themselves at least you'd know who they were. As it is, one, or a few 'bad apples' can spoil the good name, honor, etc of all the rest who serve. They have been notoriously effective at getting innocent servants spat upon. The pity is that warriors like yourself can't fully appreciate what you're about until some like-minded individual on the other side, does the same thing to you, and yours. Until then, incidents like this are about soldiers in 'bad' situations and the mere civilians who get the punishment, and the blame. This message has been edited. Last edited by: popsiq, Fri 20 March 2009 09:23 PM
title: Israel troops admit Gaza abuses

content: quote: Israelis on Friday got a fuller dose of rank-and-file angst over their army's winter assault on the Gaza Strip, as newspapers elaborated on allegations that commanders created a permissive attitude toward the killing of civilians. Soldiers' accounts of two killings of women and children appeared Thursday in Haaretz and Maariv. Both papers followed up Friday with lengthy excerpts of the soldiers’ comments about confusion and doubt over the rules of engagement during the 22-day offensive, which left an estimated 1,400 Palestinians dead. (....) +http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-gaza-israeli-troops21-2009mar21,0,2555966.story
